content.statement: vascular:venous:spj-001-anatomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:venous:spj-001-anatomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:venous:spj-001-anatomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:venous:spj-001-anatomy.

anatomic_location.depth: Deep to popliteal fascia in popliteal fossa

giacomini_drainage.description: SSV continues cranially as Giacomini vein to GSV
giacomini_drainage.significance: No true SPJ exists; treat Giacomini if refluxing

gastrocnemius.significance: May be associated with gastrocnemius vein reflux

high_termination.description: Enters femoral vein in distal thigh

giacomini_vein.definition: Intersaphenous vein connecting SSV to GSV
giacomini_vein.course: Posterior-medial thigh from SSV to posteriomedial GSV
clinical_significance: Alternative SSV drainage when no true SPJ
Route for reflux propagation between SSV and GSV
Must be identified and treated if incompetent

neural_relationships.sural_nerve: Runs with SSV below mid-calf; converges at SPJ level
neural_relationships.tibial_nerve: Deep to popliteal vessels in fossa
neural_relationships.injury_risk: Sural nerve injury is major complication of SPJ surgery

presentation: Posterior calf or popliteal fossa varicosities
diagnosis: Measure SPJ height from popliteal crease
Mark SPJ location on skin preoperatively
treatment: Prone or lateral positioning for access
Tumescent anesthesia for thermal ablation (nerve protection)
Foam sclerotherapy alternative for smaller veins

definition.@value: The anatomic termination point of the small saphenous vein, typically into the popliteal vein but highly variable in location and occasionally absent when drainage occurs via the Giacomini vein instead.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe SPJ anatomic location and common variations
Identify Giacomini vein and its clinical significance
Apply preoperative duplex mapping requirements for SSV treatment
Recognize neural structures at risk during SPJ procedures
clinical_pearls: True SPJ into popliteal vein exists in only 70-80% of limbs
Giacomini vein connects SSV to GSV - treat if incompetent
ALWAYS ultrasound map SPJ before treatment - location is HIGHLY variable
SPJ height ranges from popliteal crease to mid-thigh
Sural nerve injury is major complication - use tumescent for thermal ablation

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
